verses.verse: A man may make plans in his heart, but the LORD provides the words that his tongue utters.[a]
A man’s ways may seem honorable to him, but the LORD weighs his motives.
Entrust everything that you do to the LORD, and your plans will turn out to be successful.
The LORD has made everything for his own purposes, even the wicked for the day of disaster.[b]
The LORD abhors the proud man; be assured that such a man will not go unpunished.
Iniquity is expiated by kindness and faithfulness, and by fear of the LORD[c] man turns away from evil.
When the LORD is pleased with someone’s conduct. he makes even that man’s enemies friends with him.[d]
It is better to have little and be righteous than to acquire great riches with injustice.
A man may plan his own course, but the LORD makes his steps secure.[e]
The lips of a king utter inspired oracles; he does not err when he pronounces judgment.
Accurate scales and balances belong to the LORD; all the weights in the bag[g] are his concern.
Kings regard wrongdoing as abhorrent, for their throne’s foundation depends upon righteousness.
Honest speech is the delight of a king, and he loves a man who speaks truthfully.
A king’s wrath is like a messenger of death, but one who is wise will appease it.
When a king’s face brightens it spells life, and his favor is like a rain shower[h] in spring.
It is better to acquire wisdom rather than gold, and more desirable to acquire understanding rather than silver.
The path of the upright avoids evil; he who treads carefully preserves his life.
Pride goes before disaster, and a haughty spirit goes before a fall.
It is better to live humbly among the lowly than to share plunder with the proud.
The one who pays heed to instruction prospers, and blessed[j] is he who trusts in the LORD.
A wise man is esteemed for being pleasant, and his friendly words increase his influence.
Wisdom is a fountain of life to one who possesses it, but folly is the punishment of fools.
A wise man’s heart guides his mouth, and his lips increase learning.
Pleasing words are like a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and affording health to the body.[k]
Sometimes a path may seem to be right, but in the end it leads to death.
The laborer’s appetite works on his behalf, as hunger spurs him on.[l]
A scoundrel[m] concocts evil, and his lips are like a scorching fire.
A perverse man sows strife, and a tale-bearer destroys close friendships.
One who indulges in violence entices his neighbor and leads him into evil ways.
One who winks his eye is plotting perverse deeds; one who purses his lips is bent on mischief.
Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is gained by a righteous life.
It is better to be a patient man rather than a warrior, one who controls his temper rather than one who captures a city.
The lot[n] is cast into the lap, but the decision comes from the LORD.
